Hi Dr. Mike! First I would just like to say I love your videos and the knowledge you spread. Thank you so much for using this as a platform. I am in the medical field as well (med/surg nurse). I found this video very interesting and you expressed an opinion opposite of what I would think and was wondering if I could email you? It's in regards to using a FP to prescribe antidepressants as a first line vs going to see a specialist. I always thought it would be better to see a specialist for therapy sessions vs starting medicine right away. I believe professionals in healthcare could learn a great deal from each other and would love to hear an FPs reasoning and point of view as well as ask some follow up questions. It would also help to educate me as family and friends often come to me for advice and I would hate to lead someone astray from such an important topic. I will also read the articles you posted. Thank you!
denny3027@gmail.com

snippet.textDisplay: a few years ago, I was having a very difficult time finding a psychiatrist to take my insurance. during that time, my GP was able to prescribe me the medication I was on at the time, and offered to work with me if I needed a dose change or another medication added. I do need to see a psychiatrist because I have severe mental illnesses, but I’m thankful my GP was there as my ally during a difficult time. family medicine is hugely underrated, yet so important to public health and well-being.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think it's particularly harmful when you see a specialist before other things have been properly ruled out. My husband and I were pretty thankful for our family care doctor, because she decided to evaluate the potential physical factors that may cause depression-like symptoms before giving him anything for depression...and it turned out to be a vitamin D deficiency that was causing his symptoms. (we live in an area that gets a lot of snow...so winter means we don't get a whole lot of sun on our skin...>.<) After he started taking a multi-vitamin and vitamin D supplements, his symptoms started to decrease.
Thank goodness for good doctors! Though, I've also had some bad doctors who were too quick to refer as well. x.x

snippet.textDisplay: In my country, insurance won't cover long-term treatments unless there's a medical document signed by a board-certified psychiatrist, no matter how brilliant the family doctor is. When family doctors prescribe antidepressants it's either a temporary measure until a specialist can confirm the definitive diagnosis or the patient has a pre-existing condition the family doctor can handle on their own. I wouldn't want to give my patients the idea that you won't ever need a psychiatrist unless you're "crazy" enough to be in an institution because it's not often true.

snippet.textDisplay: When I was going through IVF, I was very anxious. How painful will the injections be? How much will this cost? What if it doesn’t work? What if the hormone therapy causes cancer? What if, what if, what if... so, I had my annual check up with my primary care doctor scheduled and I was telling her how I was feeling and she was very quick to prescribe an anxiety medication. I decided to check with my IVF doctor before I started taking it, and he was very quick to tell me not to use it at all because there was some evidence that this particular anxiety medication could cause birth defects. My primary care doctor, knowing that my intended goal was to become pregnant by IVF, should have known that and should not have prescribed it for me. My IVF doctor told me that because my anxiety was very situational, I would be better off going to counseling, but he said to make sure that I went to someone who had experience in counseling infertility patients. Counseling was more expensive than pills and it wasn’t an instant chemical relief like pills would have provided. Instead, my counselor taught me relaxation techniques and coping strategies so that I could set myself up for success. She had me start journaling and going for walks every day even when it was cold outside just to get some fresh air and sort of re-center my perspective every day. In the long run, I feel like going to counseling was a much better decision than taking pills for me

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm active duty military. Most PCMs will refer you to behavioral health to see a psychologist or psychiatrist. After being referred it took almost 3 months to get an initial appointment, which was basically a screening, and another 2 months for the appointment where I was prescribed the medication I needed. The US Military accounts for something like 1-2% of the US population in total. Imagine throwing the 40-66million at such a small number of mental health professionals. It would be a nightmare.

Celebs need to remember that they shouldn't be making recommendations about things they aren't trained to talk about.

snippet.textDisplay:
As a mental health clinician, the only complaint I have when patients are prescribed meds is relevant to both primary care physicians & psychiatrists. When it comes to the care of immigrants & people whose primary language is NOT English, very well-meaning physicians seem to lack awareness of cultural norms, including any stigma they may face when discussing mental health issues & receiving MH treatment (especially psychotropic meds). They may not be comfortable disclosing certain information or raising any questions/concerns.

Because PCP’s are in the best position to identify a mental health need, I would also like to know that they are properly assessing whether a psychotherapy referral is warranted.

My mental illnesses are under control thanks to my PCP and the psychiatrist he referred me too. snippet.textDisplay: Health services let alone mental services are so difficult in America. I tried so hard trying to find someone who could see me for severe depression and suicidal thoughray. No insurance. Didn't qualify for the low cost county health services, was turned away. It was a dead road with no way to get help. After a year..what are you gonna do? Nothing good. Eventually I found somewhere in a big city. Called, walk in only. "But it's 10am, you won't get seen today either way". Months later I had the will to make the trip. And after 4hours and going through a bunch of emotional and upsetting evaluations. I still left not talking to a Dr. Or getting help. I felt worse. I had to get the energy to drive down there again very early and make sure I was one of the first people.... And do it all over again. Got 30 days of medication. Felt better, not great. But I'll take it! "You need to see your regular gp for refills". There are no gp that see non-insurance patients here... I would of done that to begin with if I could. So I ran out. And it was a living hell 1 week later. Found a service online that would call in medication to the pharmacist. 40$ got me the approval to get more. I wasn't happy to use that sort of service. I wish I knew about it years ago. But what are you suppose to do in America?

snippet.textDisplay: Good points, HOWEVER I can't say that I agree with some of your specifics in point #3. You are saying you know that not all patients coming in with anxiety and depression need medication. And you understand the efficacy of therapies like CBT and DBT.. but a family medicine doctor still has to refer out for these options! So you will have to refer to a "specialist" or really therapist/counselor, psychologist or psychiatrist.  You say it only makes sense that "we continue this line of treatment (meds) until it passes the complexity line to refer to a specialist. I do agree you may have an existing relationship with a patient so you know them but you most certainly will not know what is best to treat their depression if you are not presenting all treatment options from the beginning which includes referring to a therapist for patient-centered behavioral emotional therapy options rather than only biomedical ones (medication). Medication should not be the "first line" recommended by a family practioner for mental health issues.

snippet.textDisplay:
My psychiatrists (wrongly) had me on an antipsychotic med for 6 months, & they wanted to add antidepressants. They knew from my first ER trip, that my thyroid levels were MORE THAN DOUBLE the normal amount. (2 ER trips were made because I was going through terrible psychosis.)
My family doctor stepped in 5 months into the antipsychotic treatment, & told me to remind the psychiatrists that very high levels of thyroid often results in psychosis.
7 months in, they still didn’t know what was wrong, & I told them I was sick of the akathisia (which was a terrible side effect caused by the antipsychotic meds) & I asked them if my psychotic episodes, from months prior, could have been due to my very high levels of thyroid at that time. They said “Yes”. I said “K, I’m not taking the antipsychotics again. Thanks for the last 7 months.”
I started to feel normal a few weeks after being off of the antipsychotic & I’ve been great since being off of them. This is thanks to my family doctor. I used to go through periods of being very depressed, but I know I don’t have clinical depression. CBT is helping me— which is prescribed by my family doctor. She’s f’n great. 👍🏼

Being depressed ≠ having clinical depression, ∴ ≠ needing antidepressants. There are differences in being severely depressed & having clinical depression!!!

snippet.textDisplay: My own experience with anxiety was a nightmare until I found a therapist and began CBT. I was unable to find a primary care physician who seemed interested in helping me, and I often felt judged when I would talk about my symptoms. None of the PCPs I saw offered to refer me to a therapist; medication was the first line of treatment, and they did not even let me know that therapy was an option. I went a few years without any treatment because I wasn't comfortable taking medication and didn't know how to access therapy. I tried lots of things on my own, but nothing worked and I was miserable all the time. I was finally referred to a therapist by a friend, and I completed a year of CBT, which helped me tremendously--I can't even tell you how thankful I am for this. I wish this had happened sooner, and I feel like it could have if my early interactions with healthcare providers had been different. It breaks my heart that there are people out there stuck like I was and not knowing where to turn for help, as well as people who are immediately put on medication when they could benefit more from therapy, like I had. I think I was lucky to find therapy that was affordable for me, which is probably not the case for a lot of people, but I also think a lot of people don't know that there are real options for them beyond medication because no one is telling them about it or helping them know where to look.

snippet.textDisplay:
As a preface, I'm majoring in neuroscience and behavior and have struggled with mental health issues myself. While I know this doesn't make me an expert by any means at all, what I can say is that my horrible downward spiral began because my pediatrician prescribed my first antidepressant, and when that didn't work, I saw a nurse practitioner. I suffered for YEARS, and it wasn't until I saw a psychiatrist that I got any real help or relief.


I know that a sample set of literally 1 person isn't enough to base any theories on but I've seen this problem repeated so many times, I can't help but agree that psychiatrists should be the one's prescribing medications that are psychiatric in nature. I understand full well that access to mental healthcare professionals such as therapists/counselors and psychiatrists is unfortunately very limited for some people, which includes problems with health insurance coverage (I also have firsthand experience on this end of things) and the stigma against mental illness, but seriously, it is so important that psychiatrists be the ones prescribing these medications. They are the most up to date on the research, most educated in the particular field, and went to medical school which gives them the necessary context so that medications aren't prescribed to people who have other health conditions or are on other medications that could interact.


I would only ever recommend a GP prescribe psychiatric medications as a last resort- for a patient who truly has no options or cannot wait to see a psychiatrist.

snippet.textDisplay: I disagree with your stance on self diagnosis. Self diagnosing and then self medicating is dangerous. But I knew I had anxiety and depression and PTSD before I was officially diagnosed because it runs in my family and I know what the different symptoms are. The first time I went to a doctor to voice my concerns I was 16, and I told him, “I think I might have depression.” And he literally cut me off and said, “No you don’t. You’re too young to be depressed.” It was super discouraging and I didn’t reach out again until my anxiety and depression got really bad and I was finally diagnosed at 18. That’s two years that the problem got worse when it could’ve been treated and improved all because of an uneducated medical “professional” that didn’t take me seriously. When a patient comes to you with certain symptoms and they’re worried that something is wrong it’s your job to listen and take that seriously and run tests to figure out what’s going on if something is going on and then treat them accordingly. If someone says, “I think I have depression,” you can’t just brush that off because there’s a reason they’re saying that and they might have a real problem. We go to medical professionals because we mildly self diagnose because we feel something isn’t right and we’re counting on you to check and help us. Another example: I struggled with eating disorders for a long time and the first time I brought it up, my doctor at the time said, “You’re not thin enough to have an eating disorder.” Nevermind the fact that the majority of people with eating disorder aren’t underweight as the media would have you believe. Again, because of that comment I wasted more time letting the problem get worse when it could’ve gotten better

snippet.textDisplay: Thanks for this video Dr Mike  you are right! I've learned from experience. I've recently lost my health insurance due to my divorce, before my divorce, I was seeing three doctors! My primary care Physician, My endocrinologist (Cause I have a thyroid issue) and a Psychiatrist (I started going to one in 2003 because of BiPolar symptoms and BiPolar runs in my family)  I am thankful because I'm 53 and always been in pretty good health. Now my primary care physician has me on self pay and manages all my medicines and over all my medical expenses seem to only be a little more! I'm on a minimal amount of medicine for my BiPolar symptoms, some of which were caused by being in an unhappy marriage.  They do an office visit and blood tests every six months to determine my dose on my thyroid medicine. btw my Bipolar was probably never serious enough to require me to see a psychiatrist because I never attempted suicide or was hospitalized for it, I was attempting to fix my marriage but only handed my husband info to use against me later, i.e. "See everything's her fault cause she's crazy." I'm now seeing a therapist at the health department for free and she's the best therapist I've ever had.

snippet.textDisplay: Im an adult with ADHD and have taken medication as a child, and as an adult for the past 10 years.  It's very hard for me to function without my meds, as I'm basically a walking useless train wreck without them.  I was prescribed Adderall initially by a psychiatrist and had my health and script info transferred to my PC, since psychiatrist was moving across the country.   My PC had no issues filling my Adderall for nearly 10 years, but when my family and I moved hours away, I find myself suddenly unable to convince a new PC to fill the prescription I've had for a decade-even when my Dr. releases my medical history to said prospective Dr.  Apparently the behavioral health center doesn't keep records that old so they can't help me.  As a result, I have to drive 2 hours away every few months to get my medication refilled and sometimes I don't make it because I have 4 kids who are difficult to contain on long car rides.  It's quite an inconvenient mess, perhaps not as bad as other cases but frustrating none the less.

snippet.textDisplay: I have had a family doctor prescribe antidepressants ON THE FIRST VISIT. On the next, he diagnosed me with borderline personality disorder. Unable to understand him, I went to another doctor (addictions specialist) who did a long interview, which the other doc didn't at all, but then said, "You do not have ANY psychiatric disorders, and you never did. You were just a drunk." (I had been sober over a year). Within a year I was in the hospital again, in the psych ward, drenched with shame, because there was "nothing wrong with me" or else "borderline personality disorder" (which? Can't be both.) I dragged myself out of it, sober, and found a psychologist whom I worked with for years. She said she did not believe in psychiatric diagnoses and just treated patients individually. I was more or less OK (on an antidepressant prescribed BY A FAMILY DOCTOR) for FIFTEEN years, then landed back in the hospital. People reacted with disbelief, astonishment, and anger (especially family members, who accused me of "faking"). My file  from 15 years earlier said "borderline personality disorder" and "alcoholic", and I was treated accordingly in the hospital, as if I had not made any progress at all in 15 years,  They assumed I was still drinking and had a mental illness which they told me was "untreatable". I nearly did not survive the "cure", but dragged myself out of it, finally found a psychiatrist who interviewed me, stopped the interview halfway through, and said, "I'd stake my reputation on the fact that you have bipolar disorder. You are a textbook case. I don't know how all those other doctors could have missed it." In spite of this, he turned out to be an arrogant a**hole. 15 years later, my family doctor realized I had to commute for nearly 4 hours to see him and said, "You don't have to see him again." I said, "Wait, what?" My former family doctor flatly refused to prescribe for me, said it wasn't her area, and no other shrinks were available, so I assumed I was "stuck". My new family doctor said she would prescribe for me, but I had to see another psychiatrist. I held my nose and went in. I just told her I had bipolar, as I did not want to go through another meat grinder of misdiagnosis and wildly conflicting opinion. She turned out to be respectful and attentive, the polar opposite of the last one, but now, ironically, I am well enough not to need to see her regularly. She is there in case I go through a rough patch. This is, of course, only about 5% or 10% of my story. What a hell of a battlefield, and this was from doctors and "therapists" who were supposed to be helping me.  When I tried to protest any of this mistreatment,  I was told it was MY fault for "being too complicated".

snippet.textDisplay:
I began antidepressants at 14. I needed them and we didn't have a GP/primary care doctor at the time. So my mum asked her friends, who recommended a doctor who would do it without question. The question was "do you wan an upper, a downer or a balancer?". She gave me something and I began seeing a psychiatrist and counsellor. The psychiatrist swapped me to Prozac and I remained on it for 10 years. I saw that psychiatrist for a total of maybe 3 visits.


I would go to all sorts of random doctors in shopping centers because I never had a personal doctor. I received shotty care because of that but the fact that doctors can prescribe it meant that I never got the proper interviews, it was just "You need a script? Sure here you go" and I'd never see them again.



When I finally came off the antidepressants my doctor, who I only saw regularly because he had a working relationship with my psychologist, told me I was lying about my symptoms and told me not to worry because there were "new" medications on the market now and I could try them if I wanted.


That medication has actually left me with lasting side effects, the most prominent of which is a lacking labido, that I don't think will ever be repaired. Had I been referred to the appropriate place in the first instance, maybe I would have had continued care regarding my medication or given other treatments prior to because medications should really be a last resort.

snippet.textDisplay: I can only agree with Lady Gaga to a certain degree. In my experience with the physicians I've seen, they just wanted to medicate me; I've been treated for depression and anxiety since 12 years old and it never worked. I've been in rehab only to be sent to an outpatient center that wasn't qualified to help me and they never rescheduled my appointment. As an adult, I've come to the realization that maybe treatment isn't working because there's more going on under the surface. I recently went to my current physician to ask for a referral to a psychiatrist, I told her that I think this is important because medicine alone wasn't helping me. She told me that they would just put me on medication as well; which was disappointing to hear from her because that's what SHE had done in the past. Despite this, I still feel that she's the best primary care physician I've had in a while. I politely disagreed and told her that I think a combination of therapy with medication, after a proper diagnosis, would benefit me more. She listened to me and understood, then went straight to work to find a psychiatrist that I can feel comfortable with. Although I think it's very important to listen to your doctor I also think it's important for the doctor to truly listen and do their best to accommodate their patients. Also, to understand yourself and your needs; and to learn how to communicate what you want from your doctor's care. Otherwise you're not fully benefiting from treatment.

She told me that they would just put me on medication as well; which was disappointing to hear from her because that's what SHE had done in the past. Despite this, I still feel that she's the best primary care physician I've had in a while. I politely disagreed and told her that I think a combination of therapy with medication, after a proper diagnosis, would benefit me more. She listened to me and understood, then went straight to work to find a psychiatrist that I can feel comfortable with. Although I think it's very important to listen to your doctor I also think it's important for the doctor to truly listen and do their best to accommodate their patients. Also, to understand yourself and your needs; and to learn how to communicate what you want from your doctor's care. Otherwise you're not fully benefiting from treatment.

snippet.textDisplay:
While I am not inclined to take celebrity medical advice, I have personally experienced being prescribed anti-depressants with no mention at all of therapy (or information about a typical course of treatment) - when therapy is proven to increase positive outcomes over rx use alone. And in my case, a self-help CBT book was far more effective than those medications that I was left on for years. While antidepressants can be extremely useful, patients with depression should not be lead to believe that staying on medication forever is adequate treatment.
While Lady Gaga is not entirely correct - neither are you Dr. Mike.

snippet.textDisplay: On the no tests thing, a friend of mine went to the ER a few months ago. She was experiencing numbness on one side of her face, tingling down one arm and weakness on that arm too. She went to her closest ER. They did the triage thing then sent her to the waiting room for 4 hours. When they called her back told her to see a neurologist in a few days. She doesn't have insurance and can't afford a neurologist, plus the closest one to us is an hour away. She winds up back in the same ER not quite a week later with the same symptoms. She waited again for hours. I found out, picked her up took her to a different ER a town over. There they triaged her, got her back into a room, ran a urine test, a blood test (which they had to do twice because her blood did some weird thing it shouldn't have done the first time), and diagnosed her with an infection causing swelling in her upper shoulders/neck area. This swelling is what caused the tingling and numbness. They gave her meds, for the infection and the swelling and sent us home. All in 3 hours, if that.  To me, definitely not a medical professional, those symptoms say stroke so I got worried which is why we went to a different ER. She's only 21 so a stroke would probably be highly uncommon, but that first hospital did nothing but refer her to a specialist that she couldn't afford or even get to. In my area that hospital has a terrible reputation, and I swear it only gets worse.

snippet.textDisplay:
Agree that it's not a simple problem to resolve logistically, geographically, etc. However, it is also highly problematic how many primary care doctors can make potentially dangerous misdiagnoses and prescribe incorrectly.
Example: many prescribe anti-depressants to patients suffering bipolarity. Antidepressants are designed for the regular depression and although bipolarity has an element of depression, it should not be treated as depression, especially for persons with type 2 bipolarity whose depressions are very intense.

snippet.textDisplay:
Love watching your channel, Dr. Mike! I'm always interested in learning new things and think you are very entertaining😁.
I am an RN and I appreciate the respect you show toward nurses, it means a lot. I do have a question for you though that I would love to hear your thoughts on.
I have a 6 mo old baby who had a cold recently with fevers, coughing, stuffy nose, and fussiness. In nursing school, we were taught that low grade fevers (<100.4) are not alarming and don't necessarily need tylenol. I guess because it's my own child I get more concerned. My doctor told me it was ok to give tylenol if I felt my baby was uncomfortable or in pain. I also remember hearing that fevers/high body temp helps fight infection. Is that true?
So here is my question. Is giving my baby tylenol for a low grade fever preventing my baby from being able to fight off his sickness by lowering his temperature? Am I just prolonging his sickness? Is it better to just let the fever run its course? At what point should I be giving tylenol? I've read several medical articles and it seems like the evidence is very inconclusive. What are your thoughts?🤔🤔💗
